Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act - Residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant accumulated only 137 days of physical presence in Canada; worked abroad for UNICEF; maintained property and family ties in Canada
Residency_Compliance: No - failed to accumulate 1,095 days of residence within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal process under statutory framework
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, employment with UNICEF, property ownership, family connections in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to establish central mode of living in Canada despite prolonged absence
Outcome: Applicant remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada within four years before application; exception for central mode of living
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, with deference to Citizenship Judge's expertise
Decision_Rationale: Extensive absences not justified under temporary absence or central mode of living exceptions; insufficient residential presence as required by law

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence within the four years preceding the application; time spent studying abroad did not count toward residency
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from citizenship judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required 1,095 days of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The residency requirement ensures 'Canadianization'; absence from Canada for extended periods, including for study, does not fulfill the statutory obligation

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 621 days out of the required 1095 days in the four years preceding application.
Absence due to spousal support during husband's temporary work assignment abroad.
Prior to absence, applicant lived and worked in Canada, paid taxes, and established a home.
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient physical presence but maintained strong ties to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to Federal Court - Trial Division following denial by Citizenship judge
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Proof of home establishment in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship judge failed to properly consider temporary nature of absence and ties to Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-year residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act with allowance for temporary absences
Decision_Rationale: Absence was temporary and justified by spousal support.
Applicant maintained significant ties to Canada.
Citizenship judge erred in failing to properly assess the temporary nature of the absence and the strength of the applicant's connections to Canada.
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court - Trial Division

Application_Facts: Appellant was physically present in Canada for only 232 days over a four-year period; maintained a home in Canada; paid taxes as a resident; promoted Canadian interests in Hong Kong; absences were due to business responsibilities in Hong Kong
Residency_Compliance: No, did not accumulate at least three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal involved a trial de novo before the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, ownership/maintenance of home in Canada, tax filings, promotion of Canadian interests, nature and purpose of absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration that connection to Canada was more substantial than to Hong Kong
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residence under Section 5(1)(c) requires both physical presence and intent to reside, with stronger ties to Canada than to another country
Decision_Rationale: Appellant's absences were not temporary; business responsibilities in Hong Kong outweighed his connections to Canada; residence requirement not satisfied despite some ties to Canada

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess risk in PRRA
Application_Facts: Applicant provided credible new evidence of domestic violence and honor killing risk in Turkey
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer failed to transparently address all evidence, including contradictory information in state protection reports
Evidence_Used: State protection reports, applicant's evidence on domestic violence and honor killing risk
Evidentiary_Deficiency: PRRA Officer ignored contradictory evidence within the same reports
Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Protection from removal due to risk of honor killing
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of transparency and failure to consider all relevant evidence

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Refusal of exemption from immigrant visa requirements
Application_Facts: Applicants argued procedural unfairness due to unaddressed documents and incorrect assessment of children's best interests
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to address all submitted documents
Assessment of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Documents submitted by applicants regarding humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Outcome: Officer's decision found to be reasonable and procedurally fair
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA s.25(1)
Decision_Rationale: Officer considered all relevant evidence and applied the correct legal test

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada on a temporary visa and remained beyond the authorized period before applying for refugee protection.
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of IRB decisions
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony regarding fear of spousal abuse
Documentary evidence on country conditions in Jamaica
Record of visa entry and expiry dates
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider key evidence supporting subjective fear and state protection gaps
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found lack of subjective and objective fear; court found assessment patently unreasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a new panel of the IRB
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter for state protection analysis
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board inadequately analyzed applicant’s fear and Jamaica’s capacity to protect victims of domestic violence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 114(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: After refugee claim was denied, applicant remained in Canada despite being subject to a removal order.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant under removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging basis of original refugee determination affecting removal liability
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court authority to review IRB decisions impacting enforceability of removal orders
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on domestic violence in Jamaica
IRB decision record and removal order documentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board overlooked credible evidence of risk and misinterpreted state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant’s credibility; court found this assessment unreasonable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee protection denied, removal order issued
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case referred back for re-determination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and refugee status recognition
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-hearing before a different IRB panel
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of persecution or cruel and unusual treatment due to domestic violence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient analysis of Jamaica’s ability to protect women facing domestic abuse; errors in evidence interpretation
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 12, 13, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations
Application_Facts: The Band Council stopped holding membership meetings, added ineligible members, and ignored appeals. The Minister dismissed an election appeal without verifying voter list validity or ensuring procedural fairness.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to hold membership meetings
Dismissal of election appeal without procedural fairness
Jurisdictional_Issue: Band Council acted outside its jurisdiction
Outcome: Court ruled in favor of the applicant, ordering the Band Council to revise the membership list and declaring the Minister's actions unreasonable.
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of unreasonableness of Minister's actions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory compliance under the Indian Act and related regulations
Decision_Rationale: Band Council breached rule of law by acting outside jurisdiction; Minister's decision lacked justification and procedural fairness.

Violation_Type: Failure to independently assess minor's claim
Legal_Provision_Violated: Procedural fairness under Section 2(e) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Applicants are Tamil; principal applicant's NIC was mistakenly dismissed; evidence of persecution against young Tamil women in Sri Lanka
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide reasons for rejecting documentary evidence
Failure to assess minor’s claim independently
Evidence_Used: Country condition reports on Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not properly consider credible documentary evidence
Lack of analysis on risks specific to young Tamil women
Credibility_Assessment: Erroneous dismissal of NIC as non-credible without sufficient justification
Insufficient reasoning for overall lack of credibility
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claims rejected due to perceived lack of credibility and inadequate risk assessment
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee determination decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different panel of the Immigration and Refugee Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty to consider best interests of the child
Decision_Rationale: Board failed in duty of procedural fairness, particularly regarding credibility findings and independent assessment of minor's claim

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breaking and entering with intent to commit an indictable offence

Violation_Type: Failure to provide adequate state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96, 97
Application_Facts: Ms. Myle experienced domestic violence in St. Vincent and fears persecution due to lack of effective state protection
Procedural_Issue: RPD dismissed claim twice without adequately addressing updated country evidence or credibility of testimony
Evidence_Used: Information on shelters and police response in St. Vincent
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD relied on outdated or incomplete country information
Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Myle's testimony found credible by reviewing court
RPD's negative credibility finding deemed unreasonable
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of harm due to failure of state protection
Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to consider current evidence on domestic violence and state protection in St. Vincent
Shelter operations and police effectiveness were not properly assessed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Officer breach procedural fairness or misapply the hardship test under subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; no certification question granted
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations due to separation from family and community
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Unusual and undeserved or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of decision under administrative law
Application_Factor: Ability to reintegrate into home country
Crimes.Authority: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 25(1)

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, established family and community ties in Canada
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Visa overstay applicant seeking permanent residency on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; no certification question granted
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds requiring unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably assessed factors and found no justification for exemption

Application_Facts: Applicant feared returning to Somalia due to clan affiliation and perceived Westernization
Officer found no personalized risk due to clan affiliation or perceived wealth
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed whether the Officer's rejection was based on errors in law or fact
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence showed generalized risks but no specific targeting of the Applicant
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating personalized risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk of persecution or harm under sections 96 or 97 of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision was reasonable and supported by evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization engaging in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Haqi was a member of KDPI, which engaged in violent acts against governments including civilian and military targets.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for immigration or refugee protection
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenged Board's jurisdiction and interpretation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether the Board had authority to interpret IRPA provisions on subversion
Crimes.Evidence_Used: KDPI’s history of violent actions and organizational objectives
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found Haqi's justification under international law unconvincing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deemed inadmissible due to membership in subversive organization
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question or overturning of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: KDPI engaged in subversion by force; membership sufficient for inadmissibility regardless of individual intent or temporal involvement
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration laws
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization engaging in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Haqi’s membership in KDPI, an organization conducting armed opposition against Iranian government
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Immigration applicant with alleged ties to banned organization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Challenge to Board’s interpretation of 'subversion by force'
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board’s authority in interpreting IRPA security provisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of KDPI’s violent activities and political aims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims of lawful resistance not accepted
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Maintained inadmissibility based on organizational affiliation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation consistent with precedent and statutory language
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Affiliation with group using force to undermine government constitutes non-compliance with immigration law

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion by force
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Engagement in violent acts aimed at overthrowing a government
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Threat posed by transnational armed organizations
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: KDPI’s use of violence against state institutions and civilians
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in group designated as subversive under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Armed attacks, insurgency, and attempts to destabilize government
Crimes.Leadership_Role: No indication of leadership role; general membership cited
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Board relied on documented history of KDPI activities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Whether membership alone triggers inadmissibility despite claimed humanitarian motives
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of organizational conduct and declarations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s justifications not sufficient to rebut presumption from organizational conduct
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of distinction between combatants and civilians in KDPI operations
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 34
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'subversion by force' in immigration inadmissibility context
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Permanent inadmissibility and denial of entry to Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false representations (regarding refugee claim withdrawal)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration enforcement and deferral of removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the officer's decision to deny deferral of removal reasonable under IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer assessed credibility of fraud allegations and hardship claims
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged fraud, risks in Malaysia, children's best interests, psychological hardship
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s.48 – Enforcement of removal orders
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicants claimed fraud and hardship as grounds for deferral
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No exceptional circumstances such as risk of death or inhumane treatment found
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Limited discretion for deferral under IRPA s.48
Crimes.Application_Factor: Children's best interests, alleged fraud, country conditions in Malaysia
Crimes.Authority: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Federal Court
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Allegations of misrepresentation regarding refugee claim withdrawal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.48 – Duty to enforce removal orders promptly
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants sought deferral due to fraud, risks in Malaysia, and children’s educational needs
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failure to comply with removal order despite enforcement
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fraudulent activities impacting immigration status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral reviewed under administrative process
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Psychological hardship, police complaints, children's best interests, fraud allegations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer evaluated credibility of claims for deferral
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian and personal circumstances
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Exceptional circumstances required for deferral under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No risk of death, extreme sanction, or inhumane treatment established
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: CBSA enforcement officer, Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Victim of financial fraud impacting immigration proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether fraud and resulting hardship justify deferral of removal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.48
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Claims of fraud and financial loss considered but not sufficient for deferral
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Allegations of victimization by fraud assessed but not determinative
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal must proceed unless exceptional circumstances exist
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship and risk upon return due to prior fraud victimization
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed; no intervention by court
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Extent of financial loss, impact on family, safety concerns in Malaysia
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA framework for enforcement of removal orders
Crimes.Defendant_Response: N/A – Applicants were respondents seeking relief
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, police complaints, personal affidavits
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Deferral of removal on humanitarian grounds

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possible immigration misrepresentation if asylum claim was found to be fraudulent
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee Protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's rejection of testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD's assessment found flawed due to lack of rational basis
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on China's abortion policies
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Forced abortion under China's one-child policy
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Plausibility of claim and consistency with country conditions
Crimes.Application_Error: Misunderstanding pregnancy timeline, requiring undue corroboration
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence that pregnancy was further along than assumed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Rational and plausible reasoning required for credibility findings
Crimes.Application_Factor: Consistency of testimony with known facts

Crimes.Crime_Name: Violation of reproductive rights under Chinese law
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on reproductive rights violation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Error in rejecting applicant's testimony on forced abortion
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD failed to consider documentary evidence on China’s practices
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish risk, but not require impossible corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in pregnancy timeline undermined credibility assessment
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Need for rational and supported credibility findings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on reproductive control under one-child policy
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention and Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister conceded some errors but defended overall outcome

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on gender-based persecution
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution due to forced abortion under state policy
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International human rights law, Refugee Convention
Crimes.Institutional_Action: RPD rejected claim; Federal Court intervened
Crimes.Protected_Group: Women subject to coercive population control
Crimes.Risk_Factor: History of forced abortion and IUD insertion

Crimes.Violation_Type: Erroneous rejection of credible refugee claim
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Zheng’s testimony on forced abortion dismissed without valid basis
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant outside home country seeking protection
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: None found; inconsistencies not indicative of fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly assess credibility and evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Flawed due to incorrect assumptions about pregnancy
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RPD relied on implausible assumptions and ignored evidence

Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Canadian jurisprudence on refugee status determination
Application_Facts: Choovak had permanent resident status in Germany which expired; she claimed inability to return to Iran and fear of persecution in Germany
Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain valid German residency; status allowed renewal but was not renewed
Procedural_Issue: CRDD failed to properly analyze claim against Germany
Insufficient consideration of renewability of German status
Jurisdictional_Issue: Focus on Iran despite primary claim rooted in conditions in Germany
Evidence_Used: Evidence of expired German permanent residency
Evidence of ability to renew residency in Germany
Minimal evidence regarding conditions in Iran
Evidentiary_Deficiency: CRDD ignored evidence that Choovak could renew German residency
Lack of analysis on enjoyment of basic rights in Germany
Decision_Outcome: CRDD granted refugee status based on fear of persecution in Iran
Outcome: Federal Court quashed the CRDD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Application of Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: CRDD erred by not recognizing that Choovak retained rights akin to nationality in Germany through renewable residency, and improperly shifted focus to Iran when her claim centered on Germany

Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present in Canada for only 406 days over four years; primary life maintained in Hong Kong
Procedural_Issue: Respondent failed to appear; case heard twice via videoconference
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada, ties to Hong Kong
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Citizenship Judge ignored evidence of respondent's primary residence in Hong Kong
Remedy_Sought: Denial of citizenship due to non-compliance with residency requirement
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge erred in fact and law by incorrectly concluding absences were temporary despite clear evidence of established life in Hong Kong

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed statelessness and risk of persecution in Pakistan
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application filed challenging IRB's decision
Evidence_Used: IRB considered evidence regarding ability to acquire Pakistani citizenship and lack of credible persecution risk
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting statelessness or persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims found not credible by IRB
Relief_Sought: Overturning of IRB decision on refugee status
Decision_Rationale: Applicant could acquire Pakistani citizenship and failed to provide sufficient evidence of persecution

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in an organization with a history of subversion or terrorism
Crimes.Application_Facts: Gebreab joined EPRP in 1986, after its violent phase in the 1970s; Board found EPRP to be a continuous organization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether the correct legal test for organizational continuity was applied
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Historical activities of EPRP in the 1970s, organizational structure and continuity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; focus on organizational continuity
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible due to membership in EPRP
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Immigration Division's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for factual findings, correctness for legal test
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: EPRP considered a continuous organization that had engaged in subversion; membership triggers inadmissibility regardless of timing
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Application_Facts: Gebreab joined EPRP in 1986 when it was not violent; Board found EPRP’s 1970s activities sufficient to classify it as subversive
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Correctness of legal test for organizational continuity
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Historical record of EPRP’s 1970s subversive activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Assessment focused on organization, not individual credibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Found inadmissible due to EPRP’s past subversive acts
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Correctness for legal interpretation, reasonableness for factual findings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Organization’s past engagement in subversion is sufficient for inadmissibility, even if ceased before membership

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential risk due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Membership in organization previously engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with EPRP, which committed terrorist acts in the 1970s
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Terrorist and subversive acts in the 1970s
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Board accepted historical evidence of EPRP’s terrorist activities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Continuity of EPRP as an organization from 1970s to 1986
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and historical evidence of EPRP’s activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Focus on organizational conduct, not personal involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Timing of membership relative to violent period
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'engaged in terrorism' regarding organizational continuity
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility to Canada, judicial review dismissed

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim rejection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of natural justice principles or Charter rights in credibility assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to inconsistent statements and implausible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Authority of visa officers to assess Convention refugee claims overseas
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on fear of persecution
Crimes.Application_Factor: Overseas location of applicant affecting procedural rights

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Credibility and truthfulness requirements
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Iraq with inconsistencies in details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in decision-making
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Visa officer authority over overseas applicants
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, consistent evidence supporting persecution claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to contradictions and implausibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn visa officer's rejection of refugee claim
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Visa officer acted within discretion and followed proper procedures
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa officer at Canadian diplomatic mission abroad

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section related to removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Samaroo failed to report for removal despite knowing the order; ignored legal obligation after negative immigration decision
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes, prior misrepresentations contributed to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister raised misconduct shortly before hearing
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review applications
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of false claims, visa application fraud, and non-compliance with removal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None noted; evidence of non-compliance was clear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Samaroo found not credible due to history of deception and non-compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed on grounds of unclean hands
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refusal of permanent residence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturning of removal order and grant of permanent residence
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary power to dismiss based on unclean hands
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Repeated abuse of immigration system outweighed family unification interests

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain immigration visa
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unclean hands due to fraudulent conduct in visa application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Samaroo deemed lacking credibility due to intentional falsehoods
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Visa application records, refugee claim documents, removal order history
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Intentional deception to gain immigration benefit
Crimes.Application_Error: Material misrepresentation in visa and refugee application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Balance of integrity of immigration system vs. individual rights
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Discretion to dismiss for unclean hands
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of abuse and lack of remorse
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Yes, false statements in visa and refugee applications

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review involving misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Dismissal of application due to unclean hands and systemic abuse
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found to have repeatedly abused the system
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Pattern of false claims, visa fraud, and non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on misrepresentation and removal compliance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Pattern of deceit and failure to comply with removal
Crimes.Application_Error: Multiple instances of fraud and non-compliance
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Integrity of administrative process vs. equitable considerations
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Court’s discretion to dismiss for unclean hands
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of good faith participation in immigration process
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Yes, supported by false documentation and claims

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee appeal procedures
Governing_Law: Principles of administrative law regarding standard of review
Application_Facts: Meilina claimed refugee status but was denied by RPD based on internal flight alternative; RAD upheld decision using reasonableness standard; Federal Court found appeal process flawed
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide proper appellate review
Lack of adequate reasoning in upholding RPD decision
Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of RAD's duty to defer to RPD findings
Evidence_Used: RPD findings on internal flight alternative
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient justification for deferring to RPD on mixed fact and law issues
Credibility_Assessment: Assessed by RPD; not independently re-evaluated adequately by RAD
Standard_of_Review: Correctness standard implied by Federal Court for legal questions
Decision_Rationale: RAD must conduct meaningful review of RPD decisions involving mixed fact and law; mere deference insufficient when legal or procedural errors are present

Application_Facts: Applicant withdrew sponsorship application due to income ineligibility and later requested reconsideration; immigration officer refused, citing functus officio.
Procedural_Issue: Officer incorrectly applied functus officio doctrine and failed to exercise residual discretion to reconsider the withdrawn application.
Evidence_Used: Evidence that the officer had discretion to reconsider the application.
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found error in the officer's application of functus officio.
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted to another immigration officer for reconsideration.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Administrative decision-makers retain discretion to reconsider decisions unless legally barred.
Decision_Rationale: The functus officio doctrine does not apply where a decision-maker retains residual discretion to reopen or reconsider a matter; the officer erred in refusing to consider reopening.

Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether the elimination of a job position constituted a 'discontinuance of function' under the Canada Labour Code
Legal_Issue: Did the Adjudicator correctly determine that there was no discontinuance of function under Section 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application in Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: The Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence to support their claim
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Adjudicator's decision upheld
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant had the burden to prove lack of economic justification and improper notification
Legal_Rule: Section 242(3.1)(a) bars complaints if dismissal is due to lack of work or discontinuance of a function, unless economic justification is proven
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unjust dismissal due to elimination of position without economic justification or proper notice
Outcome_on_Merits: Adjudicator's decision found reasonable; complaint not barred by jurisdictional provisions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of economic justification, notification of termination
Legal_Framework: Canada Labour Code, Part III – Unjust Dismissal
Defendant_Response: Respondent claimed discontinuance of function; Adjudicator found no economic justification
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Adjudicator’s jurisdictional ruling
Outcome: Application dismissed; costs awarded against the Applicant
Legal_Provision: Section 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CFIA's decision not to revoke appointment and adequacy of alternative remedy
Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act, staffing principles
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review, appeal, re-determination, second judicial review
Evidence_Assessment: Use of 2006 eligibility list for different position, failure to address lost promotion opportunity
Decision_Outcome: CFIA's decision found unreasonable, set aside by court
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Backx) to demonstrate unreasonableness of administrative decision
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions reviewed on reasonableness standard: justification, transparency, intelligibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of staffing principles, inadequate remedy for lost promotion opportunity
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim allowed; decision set aside and referred for re-determination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of outdated eligibility list, nature of appointment process, lack of meaningful remedy
Legal_Framework: Federal public service staffing regime, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: CFIA allowed grievance but refused to revoke appointment, offered new selection process
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of staffing process, eligibility lists, decision records
Remedy_Requested: Revocation of Griffith's appointment, restoration of fair promotion opportunity
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, matter referred for re-determination by new decision-maker
Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of the Public Service Employment Act and principles of administrative law
Authority: Federal Court, Federal Court of Appeal

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses

Risk_Assessment: High risk of continued threats if returned to Mexico City

Fear of being tracked in Mexico City

Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness, misinterpretation of evidence
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 11(1)
Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' claimed ages, identities, and relationships were inconsistent
Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, documentary evidence, field investigation findings
Basis_of_Claim: Inconsistencies in ages, identities, and relationships
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies between oral testimony and submitted evidence despite unreliable Indian documents
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness; decision upheld
Document_Fraud: Questionable authenticity or reliability of Indian documents

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.106, Refugee Protection Division Rules s.7
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided a birth certificate and Panamanian driver's license with inconsistencies in names; explanations deemed implausible by the Board.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Provided documents with inconsistent information and failed to offer credible explanation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to meet burden of proof in identity establishment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent documentation and lack of supporting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Explanations found implausible by the Board
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board concluded applicant failed to establish identity
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Successful refugee claim based on established identity
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Burden of proof on claimant to establish identity
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient and inconsistent documentation; failure to provide reasonable explanation for discrepancies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to establish identity under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.106, Refugee Protection Division Rules s.7
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided limited documentation (birth certificate, driver’s license) with name discrepancies; did not take sufficient steps to obtain additional documents.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to comply with documentation requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible identity documents or plausible explanation for absence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Explanations considered implausible; insufficient efforts to retrieve documents
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board found applicant did not meet burden of proof for identity
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee with verified identity
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimant must provide acceptable identity documents or reasonable explanation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Documentation insufficient and uncorroborated; explanations not credible

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Authenticity of identity documents in immigration context
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant established identity with credible documentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA Section 106, Refugee Protection Division Rules Section 7
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Documents questioned due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board reasonably doubted authenticity of submitted documents
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inability to explain discrepancies in documents
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Claimants must provide acceptable identity documentation or reasonable explanation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant failed to prove identity through credible means
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and related rules
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question and allowance of judicial review
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA Section 106, Refugee Protection Division Rules Section 7

Evidence_Sufficiency: Mr. Bulgak provided evidence suggesting Sudan as the likely country of removal
Evidence_Type: Evidence of lack of connections in Sudan
Sentencing_Issue: Deportation order due to inadmissibility under IRPA

Legal_Issue: Failure to consider foreign hardship due to lack of confirmed removal country
Decision_Outcome: IAD denied stay of deportation without assessing foreign hardship
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove likely country of removal on balance of probabilities
Legal_Rule: IAD must consider foreign hardship if likely country of removal is established
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence suggesting Sudan as likely country of removal
Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation based on humanitarian grounds
Outcome: Application granted, case remitted for redetermination

Legal_Issue: Failure to assess foreign hardship due to unconfirmed removal country
Evidence_Assessment: IAD failed to assess foreign hardship despite evidence of likely removal country
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must establish likely country of removal on balance of probabilities
Legal_Rule: Foreign hardship must be considered if likely removal country is established
Grounds_for_Claim: IAD required 'confirmed' rather than 'likely' country of removal
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence indicating Sudan as likely country
Lack of personal connections in Sudan
Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Outcome: Application granted, case remitted for new hearing

Evidence_Sufficiency: Scant evidence sufficient to trigger foreign hardship assessment
Evidence_Type: Evidence of no ties to Sudan
Sentencing_Issue: Deportation order due to inadmissibility under IRPA

Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence suggested Sudan as likely country of removal
Evidence_Type: Evidence of lack of familial or social ties in Sudan
Sentencing_Issue: Deportation order issued due to criminal inadmissibility

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in failing to perform a separate analysis under section 97 of the IRPA?
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 97
Evidence_Assessment: Documentary evidence showing persecution of CUD members
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case referred back for redetermination under section 97
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate risk upon removal
Credibility_Factor: Board accepted the applicant's CUD membership
Legal_Rule: Under section 97 of the IRPA, the Board must assess if removal would subject the claimant to torture, risk to life, or cruel and unusual treatment
Outcome_on_Merits: Section 96 findings upheld; section 97 analysis remanded
Key_Evidence_Considered: Membership in CUD, documentary evidence of persecution
Defendant_Response: Board denied refugee claim without analyzing section 97 risks
Outcome: Case remanded for reassessment under section 97

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board committed a reviewable error in assessing the applicant's refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible by the Board
Evidence_Type: Evidence regarding risks to returning failed refugee claimants in Sri Lanka
Legal_Provision: Standard of review: reasonableness for findings of fact and credibility; correctness for questions of law
Application_Error: Alleged failure to address risks to returning failed claimants; challenged burden of proof language
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to factual and credibility findings
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal questions
Application_Factor: Burden of proof on applicant, credibility of testimony

Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff's statement of claim discloses a reasonable cause of action in negligence
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff's claim found vague, lacking specific facts and particulars
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish all elements of negligence
Legal_Rule: To establish negligence: (1) damage, (2) causation, (3) breach of standard of care, (4) duty of care, (5) proximate cause, (6) absence of contributory negligence
Standard_of_Review: Reasonable cause of action test; generous interpretation applied
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged negligence by defendant causing damage
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed due to failure to plead essential elements
Key_Evidence_Considered: Statement of claim filed by plaintiff
Defendant_Response: Motion to strike out for failure to disclose cause of action
Outcome: Claim struck out without leave to amend; dismissed as frivolous and vexatious
Legal_Provision: Rules of Court regarding pleading standards

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PSIC's decision upheld as reasonable and procedurally fair

Crimes.Crime_Name: Fabrication of evidence to affect tribunal proceedings
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over disclosure and investigation refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether PSIC erred in refusing to investigate under s. 24(1) of PSDP Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDP Act)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Prior OIC findings considered sufficient; no new investigation warranted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonableness or breach of fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant allowed to submit written arguments; opportunity provided
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 24(1) of PSDP Act allows refusal if matter adequately dealt with elsewhere
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with consideration of procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of fabrication of evidence in tribunal context
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed; PSIC decision found reasonable
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: OIC's prior assessment and applicant's submissions
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Public Servants Disclosure Protection Act (PSDP Act)
